--- title: "Pandas — filtrowanie trzema sposobami" format: html: code-tools: true --- Załóżmy prosty DataFrame: ::: {#166cab17 .cell .thebe execution_count=1} ``` {.python .cell-code} import pandas as pd df = pd.DataFrame({ "city": ["WAW","WRO","KRK","GDA","POZ"], "temp": [23, 25, 21, 19, 24], "rain": [False, True, False, True, False] }) df ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ```{=html}
city temp rain
0 WAW 23 False
1 WRO 25 True
2 KRK 21 False
3 GDA 19 True
4 POZ 24 False
``` ::: ::: ## 1) Filtrowanie maską bool (najczęstsze) ::: {#0b63a1fd .cell .thebe execution_count=2} ``` {.python .cell-code} hot = df["temp"] >= 23 df[hot] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=2} ```{=html}
city temp rain
0 WAW 23 False
1 WRO 25 True
4 POZ 24 False
``` ::: ::: ## 2) `.query()` — czytelne warunki jako string ::: {#75c852bd .cell .thebe execution_count=3} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.query("temp >= 23 and rain == False") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=3} ```{=html}
city temp rain
0 WAW 23 False
4 POZ 24 False
``` ::: ::: ## 3) `.loc` — jawnie po wierszach/kolumnach ::: {#72a893b2 .cell .thebe execution_count=4} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.loc[df["temp"].ge(23) & ~df["rain"], ["city", "temp"]] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=4} ```{=html}
city temp
0 WAW 23
4 POZ 24
``` ::: ::: --- ### Mini-zadanie ✅ Wyfiltruj miasta, w których **nie pada** i temperatura jest **poniżej 24**, zwracając tylko kolumny `city` i `temp`. ::: {#16129a4f .cell .thebe execution_count=5} ``` {.python .cell-code} # TODO: napisz filtr na 2 różne sposoby (maską i .query()) # 1) maska bool: # ... # 2) query(): # ... ``` :::
